text: @speechieLO @expatally @Verdon Its such an important moment for our profession to choose its own destiny! Every term we use and action we take has a flow on effect. text: (6/10) As we tackle neurodiversity, particularly in the game industry, it's important to realize there are a LOT of us already here. Gamedev attracts people with anxiety. But they aren't likely to tell you if they have it. Anxious people excel in smaller, less formal groups.

BPD is believed to be neurodivergent because it physically alters the way the brain-specifically the frontal cortex (the main controller for emotional control and deduction making) looks. BPD can be diagnosed with an MRI scan.

so for clarification, cause i keep seeing people confused about it:
 - neurodiverse: representing the full spectrum of neurodiversity, including what is considered the norm
 - neurodivergent: divergent from the neurological 'norm'

Pillars of neurodiversity I've concluded so far:

- Afantasia
- Synesthesia
- Executive processing

text:
Note on the use of the word "Mad", which may be seen as ablist:
It is sometimes used to reclaim the language around neurodiversity from the medical profession, as an attempt to decolonise it. (See "Mad Theory")
We also acknowledge discomfort & apologise if we have offended.

text:
@AutisticPriest The issue is that these sorts of things get conflated with obvious dysfunction.

There *is* neurodiversity that should be celebrated instead of remediated.  But there is also neurodiversity which is basically a defect of our functions and purpose as rational animals.

text:
Please can we not use the C word when talking about dyspraxia? Telling a dyspraxic child they are clumsy is blaming them for thier neurodiversity.  You wouldn't call a child struggling with reading "stupid", so don't call a dyspraxic child "clumsy".
#dyspraxia #dyspraxiaawareness https://t.co/tbwMiTMK22

text:
Definition Friday: Neurodiversity.
The range of differences in individual brain function and behavioral traits, regarded as part of normal variation in the human population. Neurodiversity is a viewpoint that brain differences are normal, rather than deficits.

text:
That's what "neurodiversity" means. It means that a people have different types of brains. That's basically it.

Your co-worker who seems "awkward" or that person who fidgets a lot or etc. etc. etc. - those people are probably a different neurotype than you.
3/7

text:
To clarify my point -
Think of an ecosystem. You have all these different living organisms, right? Living in the same area.

Neurodiversity means that there are people of different neurotypes everywhere, interacting with you and generally existing near you.

That is a core point. Most aspects of neurodiversity are misunderstood, stigmatised and people are regularly shamed for being only who they are.

Let's get something straight:
Difficulty in *expressing* emotion, does NOT mean difficulty in *feeling* emotions.
#Autistics DO feel *strong emotions* and EMPATHY. We just don't know how to express it.
